name: AWS Storage Types Explained
description: Understanding block, file, and object storage models in AWS and their real-world use cases

cards.front: You're setting up a shared development environment where multiple servers need access to the same hierarchical file system. Which AWS storage type is most appropriate?
cards.back: Use file storage. It supports a folder-based hierarchy and is ideal for shared access scenarios such as development environments and user directories.
cards.example: An AWS Elastic File System (EFS) is mounted to multiple EC2 instances, each reading and writing to shared code repositories.
cards.subject: Storage Types on AWS

cards.front: You need low-latency storage for a transactional database that performs many small reads and writes. What AWS storage type should you choose?
cards.back: Block storage is best for low-latency, high-performance workloads like databases. It accesses data in fixed-size blocks with minimal overhead.
cards.example: Amazon EBS is used to store data for a MySQL database running on an EC2 instance, ensuring fast read/write operations.
cards.subject: Storage Types on AWS

cards.front: Your application needs to store large volumes of static media like images and videos with flexible metadata tagging. Which AWS storage model fits best?
cards.back: Object storage is ideal for storing unstructured, static data like media files. It stores data in a flat structure with metadata and a unique identifier.
cards.example: Photos uploaded to a serverless web app are stored in Amazon S3 using object storage for scalability and durability.
cards.subject: Storage Types on AWS

cards.front: Which AWS storage type would make updating a single character in a large file most efficient?
cards.back: Block storage is the most efficient because it allows updates to specific blocks without rewriting the entire file.
cards.example: An ERP system updates individual records stored on Amazon EBS volumes without reloading entire data files.
cards.subject: Storage Types on AWS

cards.front: You need a scalable storage solution for petabytes of archived image files that donâ€™t change. What AWS storage approach should you use?
cards.back: Use object storage, such as Amazon S3, which is designed for scalability and storing immutable static files.
cards.example: A media agency archives millions of photos in Amazon S3, organizing them using metadata tags.
